linkedLists

Class AbstractList<T>

  • java.lang.Object
    • linkedLists.AbstractList<T>
  • Type Parameters:
    T - Type of object to be stored in the list.
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    abstractDataTypes.AbstractDataInterface<T>, java.lang.Iterable<T>, ListInterface<T>
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    DoubleLinkedList, LinkedList

    abstract class AbstractList<T>
extends java.lang.Object
implements ListInterface<T>
    An abstract class for those methods declared by ListInterface and implemented identically in LinkedList and DoubleLinkedList.
    Author:
    kevna (Aaron Moore)

    • Field Summary

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Field and Description
      protected int length
      The current number of items in the list.

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      AbstractList()
      The constructor assigns the default length of the list (no items at construction of the superclass).

    • Field Detail

      • length

        protected int length
        The current number of items in the list.

        Storing the current number of items in the list removes the need to iterate through the entire list in order to evaluate it's length. This reduces processing time (potentially quite significantly) at the cost of an extra integer's worth of memory.

    • Constructor Detail

      • AbstractList

        public AbstractList()
        The constructor assigns the default length of the list (no items at construction of the superclass).

    • Method Detail

      • add

        public void add(T item)
        Adds an item to the list, not specifying the position. This method should add an item to the start or end of the list (at the implementor's discretion). Ideally this method will call ListInterface.add(int, Object) with a value given for the position.

        In those classes that extend this abstract class the item will be added at position 'length'. That is to say, they will be added to the end of the list. This method uses the extending class's ListInterface.add(int, Object) method as recommended.

        Specified by:
        add in interface abstractDataTypes.AbstractDataInterface<T>
        Specified by:
        add in interface ListInterface<T>
        Parameters:
        item - The item to add to the array.

      • add

        public void add(ListInterface<T> list)
        Adds the contents of another list to this list, not specifying the position. Ideally this will make recursive calls of ListInterface.add(Object) by iterating through the contents of 'list'.

        In this Implementation a 'for each' loop is used to add the contents of 'list' to this list. As recommended this method adds elements to the end of the list using add(Object).

        Specified by:
        add in interface ListInterface<T>
        Parameters:
        list - List of items to add to this list.

      • contains

        public boolean contains(T item)
        Iterator to see if an item exists in the list
        Parameters:
        item - The item to look for.
        Returns:
        Whether the given item exists.

      • getLength

        public int getLength()
        Returns the number of items currently in the list.

        This implementation uses the 'length' variable to avoid having to iterate through the entire list to count the length.

        Specified by:
        getLength in interface abstractDataTypes.AbstractDataInterface<T>
        Specified by:
        getLength in interface ListInterface<T>
        Returns:
        Number of Items in the list.

      • isEmpty

        public boolean isEmpty()
        Returns true if the list is currently empty, false if any items exist in the list.

        In this implementation the method literally returns whether the length is 0 using the 'length' variable;

        Specified by:
        isEmpty in interface abstractDataTypes.AbstractDataInterface<T>
        Specified by:
        isEmpty in interface ListInterface<T>
        Returns:
        Whether the list is currently empty.

        Specified by:
        iterator in interface java.lang.Iterable<T>
        Specified by:
        iterator in interface ListInterface<T>
